texts.shortText: Unusual calcified hydrozoan that has thick, hard stems and is often mistaken as a true coral (Order Scleractinia). The colony is bright pink or orange and shaped like a short, stout tree, with a thick, sometimes flattened base adhering firmly to the substratum and bearing one to many upright, cylindrical, branching stems that become paler towards their tips. The tiny polyps emerge from star-shaped openings in the skeleton.
Polyps about 1 mm, colonies up to 25 cm tall.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Peninsula to Algoa Bay.

Instantly recognizable to group and common on shallow reefs from about 5-100 m in depth, particularly in overhangs and on vertical surfaces.

Unlike most true corals does not host symbiotic algae (zooxanthellae) so is not dependent on light and thrives in dark habitats, such as caves. Very slow growing and can be aged by growth rings formed in the main stems, much like tree rings. Individuals can reach over 100 years in age. A protected species that requires a special permit for collection.
Feeds on small particles and planktonic organisms in the water surrounding the host

Male and female reproductive individuals (gonozooids) borne on different colonies, smaller than feeding individuals (about 0.5 mm in length), have rudimentary tentacles and bear several sporosacs. Female sporosacs each bear a single egg which develops in situ into a planula larva.

Well-known and easily recognized to genus level although in reality this is just the most common of seven regional species. The wide diversity of colours and shapes in photographed specimens under this name suggests that at least some of these actually represent other species in the genus (for details see Cairns reference below).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 42).

Cairns, SD & Zibrowius, H (2013). Stylasteridae (Cnidaria, Hydrozoa, Filifera) from South Africa. Zootaxa, 3691(1), 1-57.

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 58).
